article-doc.publication: The Wall Street Journal Interactive Edition

article-body.subhed: Boy With BB Gun, 12, Dies After Police Shooting
article-body.p: A 12-year-old Cleveland boy who was shot by police when he allegedly reached for his BB gun died Sunday morning, law-enforcement officials said.

Officers responded Saturday afternoon to a report that the boy was waving a gun and pointing it at people at a playground in Cleveland, according to police. When officers told the boy to raise his hands, police said he didn’t comply and reached to his waistband for the gun. Police fired and hit the boy in the torso.
The boy, who hasn’t been named, had an “airsoft” gun that resembled a semiautomatic pistol, police said. The orange safety indicator had been scratched off the gun, police said.

The boy was transported to MetroHealth Medical Center, but died of his injuries Sunday morning, said Sgt. Ali Pillow of the Cleveland Police Department. Two officers were put on paid administrative leave as officials investigate.
article-body.subhed: UVA Suspends Fraternal Activities Amid Probe
article-body.p: The University of Virginia this weekend suspended activities at all campus fraternal organizations amid an investigation into a published report in which a student described being sexually assaulted by seven men at a fraternity in 2012.

In a letter to the university community Saturday, President Teresa Sullivan said the Board of Visitors is scheduled to meet Tuesday to discuss the allegations contained in a Rolling Stone article, along with the university’s policies and procedures concerning sexual assaults. Students, faculty, alumni and others will be asked to hold similar discussions.
The suspension of all fraternal groups is effective until Jan. 9, Ms. Sullivan said. The fraternity voluntarily has surrendered its fraternal agreement with the university.

Mr. Sullivan also has asked Charlottesville police to investigate the alleged rape at the Phi Kappa Psi house. She said the Rolling Stone article includes details that weren’t previously disclosed to university officials.
Residents of Buffalo, which was slammed by a historic snowstorm last week, are preparing for floods, as the filthy piles of snow melt and forecast rain threatens to swell creeks and storm rains.

Gov. Andrew Cuomo said at a news conference Sunday that preparations were being made for the worst-case scenarios. Temperatures rose above 50 degrees over the weekend, and Monday’s forecast calls for rain showers and high temperatures near 60 degrees.
“Flooding in my opinion is worse than dealing with snow,” Mr. Cuomo said. “It’s not water, it’s a toxic brew…It has all sorts of sewage in it.”
While no mandatory evacuations were expected, Mr. Cuomo urged those who lived in floodprone areas, such as neighborhoods backing onto creeks, to “have a bag packed” and prepare to evacuate.
article-body.subhed: Naked Suspect Assaults Man, 84, at Airport
article-body.p: A naked man fell through the ceiling of a women’s bathroom at Boston’s Logan International Airport on Saturday, then ran out of the restroom and assaulted an elderly man, state police said.

Cameron Shenk, 26 years old, of Boston, was arrested and charged with attempted murder, mayhem, assault and battery on a person over 60, assault and battery on a police officer, lewd and lascivious conduct, and malicious destruction to property.

After crashing through the ceiling, an incident reported by a woman who was in the bathroom, Mr. Shenk assaulted an 84-year-old man, biting his ear and attempting to choke him with his own cane. It wasn’t known if Mr. Shenk had retained an attorney; his phone number couldn’t be located.
